You have at least three options:

- delete the (W)ARCs Heritrix writes soon after they're filled. Keeping 
them for at least a little while, up to your available storage, means 
you'll have some opportunity to investigate any oddities you notice 
during crawling by seeing what was actually retrieved

- simply by removing the 'writer' processor from the default 
configuration, retrieved content won't be saved -- but you'll still have 
the URLs visited and retrieved lengths in the crawl.log

- in addition to removing the 'writer' processor, you could early-abort 
many fetches as soon as you get the headers. Custom 'mid-fetch' decide 
rules on the FetchHTTP processor can do this for you. However, you 
definitely still want to get content that has outlinks (so you can 
discover them), and you'd have to take an extra step to record the 
implied length (such as the Content-Length header) of material you 
early-abort. So this last option will take extra customization, but will 
save some on bandwidth. (For example, you can early-abort all images.)

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
